Speaker: Mr DONDAS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, would you advise the House how Australia is contributing to the Bougainville peace process? What is the significance of the Technical Meeting currently being held in Canberra attended by representatives of the PNG government, the Bougainville interim government, the Bougainville transitional government and the Bougainville Revolutionary Army?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: First, I thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory for his question and say to him and the House that this government, ever since it came to office, has given a very high priority to doing our best to contribute to an end to the bloody conflict on the island of Bougainville, which is so close to Australia. We at the outset took a very strong stand against the former Chan government's decision to pursue a military solution to the Bougainville conflict and, in the end, the stand that we took was vindicated. Since June last year, the Australian government has been playing a very significant role in helping to take forward the whole of the Bougainville peace process---everything from hosting meetings in places such as Cairns, through to providing transport to a range of different meetings for the officials the Bougainville as well as the PNG government side. At the moment, out at the Eaglehawk Resort near Canberra, a meeting is taking place of the parties to the Bougainville peace process to consider a range of technical issues which are fundamental to the peace process. As the honourable member for the Northern Territory pointed out in his question, the meeting includes officials from the PNG government, as well as from theBougainville transitional government, the Bougainville interim government and the Bougainville Revolutionary Army. There are also representatives from the Solomon Islands, Fiji and Vanuatu. I understand that significant progress is being made on issues such as the drafting of a cease-fire arrang-ment, reconstruction and policing issues. Discussions are also being held on the role and structure of the peace monitoring group that is to replace the current and very successful truce monitoring group after 30 April. The delegates will also address the issue of the role the United Nations will play in the peace process. This meeting is helping to pave the way for the leaders meeting, which is scheduled to take place on Bougainville itself in June. In conclusion, Australia is doing a great deal more than providing transport and venues for various meetings in the peace process and diplomatic support for that process. I think the most fundamental role that Australia can and is playing is. the role we play in the reconstruction of Bougainville. As a government, we have committed $132.4 million to the reconstruction process over the next few years and today, as part of that package, we are announcing an additional $1 million allocation for the Bougainville provincial rehabilitation project. That will provide building materials to help rebuild schools, health facilities, roads and bridges. It will allow people on Bougainville to start to resume their normal lives. What we are doing on Bougainville-other than facilitating the peace process-is providing a peace dividend. We are ensuring that, as peace comes, the people of Bougainville on know that peace will bring better lives for them, better educational opportunities, better health services, better transport and so on. The government is proud of what it has been able to do to facilitate the Bougainville peace process. It has been a very important component of the government's foreign policy, and we will continue actively to be engaged in this issue. Minister for Resources and Energy

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. Would the minister advise whether the government's restraint of the profligate spending patterns of the previous government has yielded benefits for Australian motorists, particularly those living in country and regional Australia?

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The answer to this question is another piece of good news which will no doubt upset those opposite who do not like to hear any good news. One of the really great successes of this government in economic management is the way in which it has reined back inflation which members opposite could do absolutely nothing about. Motorists, particularly in country areas, are amongst those who are seeing the real benefits of that success in bringing inflation down to low levels. In fact, Mr Speaker, the CPI increases are now at the lowest level for 30 years-the lowest level since the Beatles and Elvis; the lowest level since Menzies and MCEwen. That brings very. real benefits to Australian motorists because federal excise rates are linked to the CPI. They are adjusted every February and every August in accordance with movements in the CPI index. Last month, Customs was able to' announce that, because of the very low movement in the CPI, there would be no increase at all in excises for this half-year period. I might add that this is the second six-monthly interval in a row that there has been no CPI increase. This means that, for more than a year now, there has been no increase in fuel excise. That is the longest periodmore than a year-without excise increase since indexation was introduced by Labor in 1983. So it does demonstrate the real benefits to all Australians of having low inflation. It does demonstrate also what would happen if there were per some chance a change of government and we were to go back to the horrible old days when inflation was out of control. Voters would be paying everywhere they went, but they would certainly be paying every time they went to the petrol bowser. Every time they went to the petrol bowser the price would be higher because Labor cannot control inflation. The CPI would go up, and motorists in electorates such as that of the member for Kennedy would be those who would be paying. Minister for Resources and Energy

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: by leave-I move: That this House: (1) censures the Prime Minister: (a) for his unwillingness to enforce proper standards in relation to his Resources and Energy Minister, who has breached the requirements of both the Prime Minister's Guidelines on Ministerial Conduct and the Senate's Register of Senators' Interests; (b) for his approval of the arrangement whereby Senator Parer was allowed to continue to own-through a company of which he and his wife are the sole directors and ownerscoal-mining shares worth in excess of $2 million, despite the fact that this is likely conflict with his public duty as Minister for Resources and Energy; (c) for his approval of Senator Parer's failure to divest himself of shares, owned personally in QCMM Group (ESP) Pty Ltd, and through Investment Management Pty Ltd (lMPL) in Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd (and through that entity in a number of other companies in the area of his portfolio responsibility); and (d) for his sweeping aside Senator Parer's failure to comply with the requirements of the Senate's Register of Senators' Interests, in that Senator Parer's Register of Interests statement: (i) fails to list shares held by IMPL; (ii) fails to list shares held personally by the Minister in QCMM Group (ESP) Pty Ltd; and (iii) fails to identify his coal mining investments as a potential conflict of interest; (2) condemns the Prime Minister for not dismissing the Minister for Resources and Energy for his clear breaches both of the guidelines on the conduct of ministers and of the requirements of the Senate's Register of Senators' Interests; and (3) further condemns the Prime Minister for failing to disclose in detail the basis for his departmental Secretary's concluding that there is no conflict of interest involved in the Minister's ownership of significant coal mining interests. This House has just witnessed the classic stonewall when you know that you are out there, that you have been caught and that you militantly and absolutely refuse to face up to your responsibilities. This is a weak Prime Minister confronted by the consequences of having to confront his own ministerial code of conduct-not anybody else's, his. He stood up in this place to make a point about the opposition, saying how much better he was in standards than they were and what a wonderful character he was in terms of his honesty and integrity in relation to the Australian people, and he has subsequently ceased to be able to enforce the code of conduct in relation to his own ministers. He has decided, after seven of them have hit the wall for their inability to uphold the standards, that he will take no more. No matter how good the case, no matter how to obvious the conflict, he will not persist in enforcing this part of his obligations as a Prime Minister. He seeks to clothe himself in an argument that the opposition is not entitled to raise these matters in parliament and that we have to come in here and join him in his dorothy dixers of self-congratulation, and if we do not engage in his dorothy dixers of self-congratulation he will take his bat and ball home as far as answers are concerned. We have had no pleasure-but are bound from a sense of duty-in raising frequently in this place his manifest incompetence in a whole range of areas of public policy and that of his ministers. We have had no problem with that. But this is not just a forum for that,  place that holds the government accountable across the board. We hold the government accountable not just for its management of the economy or other areas of public policy; we hold the government accountable for standards. Every now and then, when we find a minister in clear breach, it is our duty to stand up and raise these matters. Prime Minister, you have come down to a very innovative interpretation of your own standards, but let me remind you of them: Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. The transfer of interests to a member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment. Furthermore, you say in your standards: ... it is important that ministers and parliamentary secretaries avoid giving any appearance of using public office for private purposes. 'Avoid giving any appearance': there are no  these matters-none whatsoever. They are there baldly and they saw the demise not just  business interests associated with his portfolio, but of a couple of your other ministers--one of them your room mate who was not involved in that way. In case you think Senator Parer does not  Minister, to divest himself of the share': holdings that he has, I draw your attention to the positions he put at the time he became a minister, when he declared that his holdings in public companies, Santos and BHP, had to be divested. Was he making decisions in relation to Santos immediately? Was he making decisions in relation to BHP? Was he in a position to control anything in relation to them? Was he a large shareholder in either of those companies? Was he into them for $2 million? No, because he then had the correct interpretation of what his duty was, and that was, where a potential conflict of interest existed, you exited in accordance with your guidelines. And he did not divest to a family trust. He did not divest to his wife. He did not divest in any way, shape or form. In no way, shape or form did he divest to anybody else related to him. He was out. But what stands at the heart of this is that, while he was out of all of that, he was into this company for $2 million worth of shares. They were not worth that, though, when he became minister. They were worth about one-tenth of that when he became minister. They are now worth that. That is why your guide them to you-have words like 'appearance of a potential conflict of interest'. Because when you become minister for coal and you own shares in coal mines and those shares increase tenfold while you happen to be the minister family for coal, a reasonable perception develops out there in the community that there is the potential for an appearance at least of a conflict of interest when in fact there is a conflict of interest. He wants us to cite specific examples of where he might have made a decision that would benefit him in some way. I suppose we could talk about retention of the diesel fuel rebate scheme and his involvement in that-in fact, he identified one of his companies as having received $1.7 million per annum over three years in that particular industry--or we could talk about lifting export controls on coal. We believe that the mines with which he is associated are exporters; indeed, they would be almost unique coal mines if they were not-not completely unique, but almost unique. He led a delegation of 12 on a coal mission to India. Did he go there and say, 'You can buy from every coalmine in Australia, but not from the one that I am a substantial $2 million owner of'? He has been a key player in the government's greenhouse strategy, where the interests of the coal industry have been front and centre in the government's mind. You do not think there is just a possibility, Prime Minister, that an appearance of a conflict of interest might actually occur in relation to any of those matters? Because you are weak, Prime Minister, because you hide yourself, you are now in a situation where you dare not lose another minister-so weak you are. You are trying to raise this notion of envy on our side of the House because we do not approve of the way your minister manifestly breaches your position. You can go through all the persiflage and all the smokescreening that you like, Prime Minister, but the public out there expects an opposition to go through the process of enforcing a few standards in this place and, when a minister does not uphold those standards, mention them. What slip-sliding you did yesterday ! You wanted a notion to develop out there that these shares could not be disposed of: that this man was shackled to his shares; that this man struggling to break those shackles found that he could not get himself clear; that he was out there doing his level best to make sure that this $2 million interest did not actually remain in his possession and remain in companies within his control; that somehow he just missed that; and that, somehow, those three people-who are the only people he has to approach in order to be able to divest himself-kept him locked in there in slavery. No wonder you evaded the question on that when it was asked of you by one of my colleagues here today-it is a piece of nonsense. Then you came out with this notion that somehow or other it makes it all right because they are non-voting shares. No wonder you evaded that too. In what I read out to you, there is no distinction between voting and non-voting shares. There is a very good reason that there is no distinction, Prime Minister: it is because there is no necessary difference between the two on dividends or possibilities of benefit. In fact, if you go through the various categories in Senator Parer's company shareholdings you will find that the shares he possesses are, indeed, to a considerable degree more beneficial than some of the others. Then you came up with this other furphy that neither Senator Parer nor his wife received an income distribution from the trust either in 1995-96 or 1996-97. He may well want to say that, but we understand that, in 1996 alone, some $300,000 worth of dividends passed into or through his handswhile he was a minister-via this process. But it is an irrelevant consideration whether or not he directly perceived it, because the trust still captures all unrealised accrued capital gains which would not be distributed as income. In the same year that Senator Parer received no income from the trust, 1995-96, the net assets of a company in which he holds the contested shares grew from $15 million to $153 million. As I said, it grew lO-fold in one year. I would not mind not getting an income distribution either if I could make a 1,000 per cent capital gain in one year. If there were prior year or current year losses to offset any dividends from QCMM, then the income could be distributed in subsequent yearsupon retirement, for example-and would be completely tax free or it could be distributed to other beneficiaries of the trust. That is what is available to him, Prime Minister, apart from taking the nicker in the back pocket immediately. That is why the issue of gain arises here. That is why the issue of the perception of the possibility of gain arises here. We have those standards so that when somebody, no matter how they choose to dispense of it, receives up to $300,000 a year in dividends, they place themselves in a situation where they divest themselves of that in situations where decisions are being taken. Prime Minister, there is no difference between the situation in which he found himself with the things he divested himself of and the situation in relation to the things that he still maintains; the only difference is the size of the benefit. He divested himself of things from which he benefited somewhat and continued to hold things from which he benefited---or would potentially have benefited-a very great deal. We sit here in this chamber listening to the blandishments of the government on the so called rorts on the waterfront. What is a watersider who is being invited to improve his productivity supposed to do? What is he supposed to believe when he sees a minister sitting in this place and concealing-and misleading in the process of concealing-the fact that he can benefit, or ensure others related to him benefit, from some $300,000 a year. We ought not to be bringing the spouses of members and the children of members into this category

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Yes, but you are.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: What spouses and children do with their own business interests is their own business, but this is not. This comes through as another sleight of hand because of what you tried to portray yesterday: that the people who have the controlling interest in this are somehow or other a diversified group, namely, his children, and that he has a one in nine interest in that process. The company which controls this-the trustee company, as opposed to the private trust-has nine shares, which have not been declared in his returns, of which he holds eight. That is the controlling interest. That was another piece of your misleading yesterday-the company holds nine shares, of which he controls eight. This is not something being built up by the kids, this is not an independent activity of his children; this is, front and centre, a product of his own endeavour. They are the mechanisms that he put in place. You go and see all the battling Australians out there, all the Australians who earn an average income of about $35,000 per yearwhom you suggest that from time to time you are going to find rorts about and beat them up, who stand shoulder to shoulder with the ordinary workers in this country whom your industrial relations legislation oppresses so massively-and ask them to. think about a government that is prepared; to ignore its standards for somebody who earns 10 times what they get each year. The distinctions in the si-uations of Mr Short and Senator Parer bear! looking at. Mr Short has departed this placeiwhat did he go for? Well, he owns 6,679 ANZ shares, worth-through the Short !family trust over one per cent of the isslled share capital in QCMMPL worth an estimated $2.3 million. Short stated: ... 1meaning the trusthave held shares in the ANZ Bank for a considerable time and that this hoiding has been recorded in the register of senators' interests since its inception. Parer claims as some sort of defence that the trust has been in existence for 28 years and that he has a one-ninth interest in it; ignoring completely the situation I have referred to of the company which owns the shares. Short, while not owning the ANZ shares in his own name, declared them all-and all the shares held by the trust in his Senate register of interests, as he held an equitable interest them by virtue of being a beneficiary of the Short family trust. Parer does not disclose the fact that the Parer family trust owns 16 Cclass shares in the QCMMPL. Part of his defence is that they are non-voting shares. I have already dealt with that. Short declared the fact that he was a shareholder in Park wick Pty Ltd, the trustee of the Short family trust. Parer fails to declare the fact that he is a shareholder in Investment Management Pty Ltd-the trustee of W.R. Parer family trust which in fact, as I said, owns eight of the nine shares on issue. Short declared that he was a director of his trustee company Parkwick Pty Ltd. Parer fails to declare his directorship of Investment Management Pty Ltd. He actually stated: 1 do not control it; in fact, it is controlled by others. He is both a majority shareholder and a director of the trustee company. He was also responsible for lodging the company's annual returns with the ASC. Short declared all his shareholdings, both personal and those held by the Short family trust. Parer fails to disclose the fact that he personally holds, in his own name, 44 shares in QCM group ESPPL. Dividends from ANZ shares, in Short's case, would have been worth several thousand dollars a year only. As we have seen in the case of Parer, the dividend was worth some $300,000, in all probability, in the first year. Upon discovery by the opposition that Short had a conflict of interest, he informed the Senate that he would be disposing of his ANZ shares. Parer claims that, as QCMMPL is a private company, there is no market in the shares and 'there is just no scope for public disinvestment, as is the case with listed shares'. All he has to do is to get the prior consent of three people in order to be able to get rid of them. Prime Minister, you just do not have any standards when it comes to enforcing this area. You have none at all. This has become, after delivery, a non-core promise. We do remember your pride and arrogance when you sought to draw a distinction between yourselves and us on these matters when you came into office. We note, from that, your regular retreats. But, above all, we note this. in We note that Parer understands what his obligation is. He understands it completely. We note it even in the divestment to which you refer. We note too that, having thoroughly understood that, he has absolutely no claim of misapprehension in relation to these particular shares. Your coal minister owns $2 million worth of coal shares and you tell the Australian people, and all the editorial writers who told you exactly what your duty is, that as as you and your standards are concerned that is not a conflict of interest-apparent, real actual. You tell them that. Well, you can go and tell it to the marines, Prime Minister. know what you are: a weak, useless Prime Minister who cannot enforce decent standards in this place.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Is the motion seconded? Mr Crean-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I could perhaps start my response to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) by pointing out that the address that he has just delivered is a perfect demonparliament-the stration that you never go into a censure motion with a prepared text. If you do, you might read out something that has already been contradicted during question time. I refer to the claim made by the Leader of Opposition that the 44 shares had not been disclosed. Those 44 shares were disclosed. They were disclosed by Senator Parer to me, and ,the Leader of the Opposition has been caught short in relation to the claims that has made. But, Mr Speaker, let me go to a more serious charge against the Leader of the Opposition, who finally pumps himself up and, in a confected display of simulated outrage, endeavours to persuade the Aushe tralian people and this parliament that he is person who is interested in ministerial standconflict ards. This is the same Leader of the Opposition who stood by the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence). This is the same Leader of the Opposition who continues to stand by Senator Nick Bolkus. This is the same Leader of the Opposition who is prepared to countenance huge interest in a piggery held by the former Prime Minister. That, of course, was not conflict of interest. And this is the same Leader of the Opposition who leads a party which at no stage during the whole of this issue has met the single obligation that it required to meet if it is to make this charge stick. You can rant and rave as much as you like about large sums of money. You can grab statements out of the air about coal ministers have and coal shares-that is akin to saying a far primary industry minister should never own a farm; that is akin to saying that a federal or treasurer who has a mortgage should never take a decision on interest rates; that is akin We to creating a set of circumstances in which we end up with a government which is composed, as I said at question time, entirely of trade union officials and former ministerial staffers. Can I say very seriously to those who sit opposite that, if this kind of excursion into the of envy, if this kind of excursion into character muckraking, if this kind of attempt to drag the adult children of ministers of my government into the political combat of this more you interject, the more you proclaim your sensitivity on this issue-if you imagine by this kind of muckraking that you are making any impression on the battlers out there, if you imagine that this is really the advancing your political cause, I think you ought to give the matter a great deal more consideration. The public is fed up with this kind of politics. The public is fed up with this kind of he character assassination. The public is not far stupid. The public goes to the nub of the issue, and the public asks a few fundamental questions. The first question they ask is: was Senator Parer doing anything dishonest? No, was not. The second question they ask is: a where is the conflict of interest? There is no of interest. In all of the fulminations of the Leader of the Opposition, in all of the questions that have been asked by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), in all of the questions that have been asked by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), at no stage have they produced any evidence. They have a not produced a skerrick of evidence that Warwick Parer did anything as minister to a advance his own personal interest. Mr Gareth Evans-So what?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The Deputy Leader of the is Opposition says, 'So what?' A conflict of interest is when somebody uses his or her ministerial position to enrich his own personal interest. Let me say that again. Let me spell it out very clearly.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: He must have known.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The member for Denison will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: How could he not know?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The member for Denison.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Let me say it again so that even those on the other side may understand it. You have a conflict of interest where you can demonstrate that the minister has used his ministerial office to advance his own personal position.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: He must have known.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I warn the honourable member for Denison.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: There is no evidence that he has done that. There is no evidence at all that he has done that. At no stage did the Leader of the Opposition discharge that obligation. At no stage did the Leader of the Opposition accept the obligation to go to that issue and to demonstrate to the Australian public that Senator Parer had put his hand in the till to his own advantage, that Senator Parer had gone along to the cabinet and said, 'My family trust has got an interest in this company. I am going to do something to help that company.' At no stage did Senator Parer take any decision as a minister that advantaged the position of that company-at no stage. That is the nub of this matter. It is for that reason that I regard Senator Parer as not being guilty of any charge made against him by the Leader of the Opposition. Despite the fact that we had an hour and a quarter of question time andÂ· we had 20 minutes of hot air from the Leader of the Opposition, at no stage during all of that time did the opposition advance any new material, did they provide any new evidence, did they assert any new fact that went to that central issue. Where is the evidence of a conflict of interest? Where have you been able to tell the parliament that Senator Parer used his ministerial position to advance his own private interest? There is no evidence of that. At no stage has there been any attempt to do that. Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The Leader of the Opposition makes an interjection about standards. This is the man who is withered into silence by Senator Bolkus, the man who is humiliated into inaction by a shadow Attorney-General who is not fit to aspire to the office of the first law officer of the Commonwealth of Australia, the man who is prepared to allow people to corrupt the court processes and help Christopher Skase. He has. the nerve to come in here and traduce the reputation of a decent, honest Australian like Warwick Parer and, in the process, drag his family into it. I notice when I trawl through some of the returns that are made by people in this House that, when they are asked questions about the holdings of their wife or their husband, they say, on occasions, rather disingenuously, 'I don't really know what my wife's assets are.' They are perfectly entitled to say that. Quite frankly, I do not seek to inquire into the assets of the wives or husbands of people who sit in this parliament, and I reject the puny attempts of the Leader of the Opposition to drag Warwick Parer's seven adult children into this tawdry character assassination. That is what you have done. It is no good interjecting with confected outrage. You are the crowd that are dragging families into this. You talk about equal rights. You talk about the independence of women. You talk about the separate dignity of adult children. But when it comes to the crunch you are prepared to lump them all in with the political career of the man in the family. You are hypocrites on these things because, when push comes to shove, if you can drag a wife into it, if you can drag a child into it, you will do it. That is what Paul Keating used to do, and that is what you have done today. You parade as though you are above all of this, that you do not really want to be involved in it and you are really a little bit reluctant to be involved in it. You leave it all to Simon. You hope he makes a bit of headway but, if he falls over, that will not matter because he does have a lean and hungry and rather mean look about him. You do not really mind about that. But you cannot escape the responsibility. So can I return to what this debate is all about. It is about a very simple question, and that is: has Warwick Parer been guilty of any conflict of interest? The answer is no. Has Warwick Parer been guilty of any dishonesty? No. Has Warwick Parer been guilty of not reaching the high ministerial standards demanded by government? No. Has the Leader of the Opposition debauched decent parliamentary debate by raising this? Of course he has. Most importantly, we all know that this matter will never be written and it will probably never be reported, but we all know that this-in the words of Senator Robert Ray-is a payback for our raising Nick Bolkus. That is what this is all about. It is as cheap and common or garden variety as that. I think the Leader of the Opposition fails to understand and fails to appreciate that just as he got no political mileage or no political bounce out of that little exercise relating to others in 1996 so it is the case that on this occasion the Australian public are really sick and tired of this sort of politics. The Australian public are fed up with an opposition that, firstly, left this country in an appalling economic mess, secondly, has made no attempt in the two years that it has been in opposition to assemble an alternative policy and, thirdly, does not address the important bread-and-butter issues of the day. Let me remind members that this is the day on which the lowest unemployment rate recorded for Australia for seven or eight years has been published. Do you think the Labor Party would be interested in that? Do you think members of the Labor Party, who are meant to be out of the loins of the trade union movement and who are meant to be concerned about the interests of the working men and women of Australia, are interested? Of course they are not. All they can do is traduce the reputation of an honest man. All they can do is drag the families of ministers into parliamentary debate. All they can do is trump up phoney allegations of conflict of interest. It matters not what a person's individual wealth is, whether it be a small amount or a large amount, we are neither a nation that should resent or be jealous of people who are successful nor a nation that should deny the poorest and the impecunious the opportunity to aspire to the highest office in this country. We are in every sense an egalitarian nation. That means that we not only should respect the less fortunate and the less well off but should never sneer at, feel envious towards or resent those in our community who through their hard work and their skill have been successful. On this occasion you have got a man who in his pre-parliamentary career was very successful in business. I am proud of that. I am not ashamed of having people on my side of politics who have been successful in business. Australia is a better country, my government is a better government, this parliament is a better institution and the future of Australia will be brighter if we can attract more men and women with a business background into this place. That is very important to Australia's future. I make that comment in no small or idle way. I say to the opposition, to those who report politics and to the Australian people that, if we continue the politics of sneering at, denigrating and trying to demean personal success, we will render this parliament a poorer place. What incentive is there for any man or woman of any assets or any affairs to come into this parliament in the future. You face the prospect of having your wife and kids dragged into every parliamentary debate. You face the prospect of having every share, every asset, anything you have ever accumulated trawled through by the muck-rakers of the political staff of the opposition and the cynics in other parts of this building who are perfectly prepared to apply standards to others that they would never apply to themselves. I believe this motion represents yet another notch towards a situation where you are literally intimidating out of the consideration of a parliamentary career many men and women who can make an enormous contribution to the future of this country. And much and all as you may dress this up, you cannot avoid it. The crowning hypocrisy of this whole motion is that it is moved by the Leader of the Opposition, who is too weak, too gutless, too fearful, too trembling and too intimidated to sack Nick Bolkus. It is for that reason that I move an amendment to the motion. I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "this House censures the Leader of the Opposition for his failure to dismiss Senator Bolkus for his clear lack of the standards required to shadow Attorney-General". Mr Crean- Mr Speaker, I have a point of order before I respond to the motion. I ask you whether the amendment which has been moved is in order. I draw attention to a statement made by you in this House in November 1991Government members-Oh! Mr Crean-I see. He can forget about it, like Senator Parer can forget about his shares, can he? Mr Truss interjecting Mr Crean-You let me and don't interject, you dope.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The honourable member will raise his point of order and stop making allusions to other people. Mr Crean- Mr Speaker, this is what you had to say on that occasion: . . . the practice in the last few years in the has been that we should reverse the standard meeting procedure and allow a motion that is totally contradictory to the original to be accepted. I put to you that this motion meeting procedure which denies the opportunity for any amendment to take the exact reverse course of the original motion. The original motion, if you look at it, was censuring the Prime Minister. It is a motion now that they are moving by way of amendment that reverses that by seeking to censure the Leader of the Opposition. Are you going to uphold what :'ou believed in 1991?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: As I thought this might be raised by the honourable member, it so happens that I looked back at the Votes and Proceedings. On 24 September 1987 at page 77, on 29 November 1988 at page 939, on 27 November 1989 at page 1651, on 28 November 1991 at page 1228-and I can go on with another 30-odd examples of exactly this type of amendment being accepted. While I might have my own preference as to whether or not the ordinary procedures are necessarily being followed, it has become an established practice of this House. It has become a practice for amendments of this kind to be accepted in this House.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: If the be the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) believed what he just said in defence of Senator Parer, why did he require other minister's to divest their shares when they were caught out? Why did he insist upon them selling those shares? Why did he bring in a code of conduct after all that made no mention of having to demonstrate the actual detail? The Prime Minister's code of conduct says: ... it is important that ministers and parliamentary secretaries avoid giving any appearance of using public office for private purposes ... ensuring that no conflict or apparent conflict between interests and duties arises. We do not have to demonstrate the actual conflict, although we think we can. All that has to be demonstrated is the appearance of conflict. That is what the Prime Minister will not answer. What have we now got? We have a footnote to the code of conduct. It is written in House invisible ink. The Prime Minister makes it up as he goes along and whenever he is caught in a crisis. The only time he is forced to defend this code of conduct is when we catch is against the standard him out. We found out today that he knew that Senator Parer had shares which he had not disclosed. What did the Prime Minister do? He did nothing. He flick-passed it to the head of his department and said that he was too busy to actually deal with it. On the Kerry O'Brien program in October 1996 the Prime Minister said, 'The guidelines say you've got to get rid of shares in a company that is operating in the area of your portfolio responsibility.' People might think that the average person is silly and that we are pretty stupid, but that is pretty clear, I would have thought. I will say it again: 'You've got to get rid of shares in a company that is operating in the area of your portfolio responsibility.' Game, set and match. What have we got in relation to this? We have the minister for coal owning a coal mine. I would have thought that if he owns shares in a coal mine that is owning shares in an area directly associated with your responsibility. He has got to get rid of them. The Prime Minister asks the question: what do we expect these people to do in those circumstances? We have not, despite what he says, got a problem with people who have been successful in business coming into this House. We welcome it, we encourage it and there should be more of it. But he asks: what do you want us to do? We will tell him what we want them to do. We want them to either disclose or dispose. It is as simple as that. If they believe that they are entitled to hold shares in a business and that does not constitute a conflict or an appearance of conflict, let tliem state it on the register. There is provision on the register for that. This is what Senator Parer should have done. What sort of man is it that, in the context of the category that says 'Any other interests that may conflict with your portfolio responsibilities', declares that he is a Christian, declares that he is a ratepayer, declares that he is a taxpayer, declares that he is a father and a grandfather but does not declare he has got $2 million worth of shares in a coal company? He says, 'Oh no, I do not have to declare that. I am a taxpayer, a ratepayer and a Christian, but I am not going to tell you about my shares.' What a sham. But there is more. He actually told the Prime Minister about these shares. And what did the Prime Minister do. He is part of the cover up. What we also got yesterday was Minister Parer admitting in the Senate, after the Prime Minister had come into this House to clear him, that he was in technical breach of the guidelines. What happened to Senator Short and Senator Gibson? When the Prime Minister sought their dismissals, the Prime Minister said: Both Gibson and Short have been forced to leave the ministry simply because they were in technical default of the rules. They were technically in breach in those circumstances. They had to go. sorry about that, but they're the rules. They were the Prime Minister's words in 1996. If it was appropriate to sack them for technical breaches of the guidelines, why not Senator Parer? I will tell you why. If Senator Parer goes-apart from the fact that he would be the eighth minister in two years that this government has had to cut loose because they have either rorted or conducted something contrary to the guidelines-who is going to be behind him? The head of the Prime Minister's department, because this was the person who gave the tick to Senator Parer. This was the person who the Prime Minister gave delegated authority to to look through all of his ministers' affairs and satisfy himself that they were clear so that the Prime Minister could tell the nation that every one of his ministers was above board. The fact of the matter is that there is a technical breach admitted by Senator Parer and, on the standards of Jim Short and Brian Gibson, he should be gone on that count. The Prime Minister tried to make the distinction in his defence of Senator Parer yesterday by saying that these are non-voting shares. He did not tell people-we had to disclose it-that these 16 shares were worth more than $2 million: 'Just a small parcel of shares but, by the way, don't tell anyone they are $2 million worth.' He tried to make the point that they are non-voting shares. The point we are trying to make is that, whether they are non-voting or not, what matters is the vote in the cabinet room. It is the vote that Senator Parer is exercising because he has been given responsibility for a portfolio in an area that he holds interest in. That is where the vote is important. So far as the non-voting dimension of the shares that are held are concerned, it is meaningless, because if the shares accrue in value Senator Parer gets a benefit. Let us just look at the accrual of value in terms of these 16 shares. In 1995 they were worth $200,000. One year later when the minister was sworn into the ministry they were worth $2 million. This is a mob that has the gall to come in here to talk about the rorts I'm of wharfies. What about this rort? What about the fact that you can increase your assets, your entitlement, tenfold without even lifting a finger? What about the circumstance, as we indicated today in this parliament, when Senator - Parer was issued these shares? The Prime Minister tried to make the point that this family trust has been around for 28 years. The fact of the matter is that these shares were issued only in 1993-16 of them were issued for $1 each. Immediately their capital value became $200,000; a year later, $2 million. Don't have the gall to tell us about the poor battlers being concerned about what we are on about. They want to know how you can get into this act. They want to know how you can become a millionaire overnight when you happen to be a minister. They want to know why it is fair that, being minister for coal, can have shares in a coal mining company and get defended by the Prime Minister saying, 'There is no conflict of interest.' _ But, I tell you what, this - scam gets worse. Not only did the capital value increase from $200,000 to $2 million; these shares were issued in 1993-$1 shares, I might say to you-and immediately after the issue of the 16 shares to Senator Parer, at a meeting in February in Brisbane, they declared a dividend on those shares. This is three seconds after the original decision. Do you know what the dividend was worth from those 16 shares: $210,000. Not bad for a morning's work, that lot. And that is just the dividend. What about the capital value? But, hang on, it gets worse again. Mr O'Keefe-it couldn't.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Yes. Who was chairman of the company that issued the shares and determined the dividend? Opposition members-Senator Parer!

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Senator Parer as chair. How could he forget this? How could he think that this should not be declared? I tell you what, if this government thinks the public will buy that, they will be out of office before too long. Let me go on, again, because it was not only in 1993 that this great windfall came Senator Parer's way. It so happens that the dividend stream from all of the issues on these 16 shares since 1993-which, if they were sold, would realise more than $2 million-is $850,000. That is $850,000 in fully franked dividends. That means they do not get taxed again. They are tax free-a tax-free stream of $850,000. That is the equivalent of $1.4 million over the space of about five years. From doing what? What we also have got is a circumstance in which, in this House, the Prime Minister said yesterday that Senator Parer and his wife got nothing-nothing, mind you-in 1995-96. But what the Prime Minister would not answer was whether he was aware that Senator Parer chaired another meeting in 1995 that issued him, amongst other things, almost $100,000 in further dividends. That is in 1995-96. you There is no point in saying they went off to the family; the fact of the matter is that dividend stream went to the owners of the shares. The owner of the shares was Senator Parer's private company and that private company is controlled by himself and his wife. He owns eight shares; his wife owns one. Both are directors; both are in total control. They can make decisions as to where that money goes, but the income stream went to them. That is what we are dealing with here. We are dealing with the fact that this information was hidden from the public when it should have been disclosed. The minister knew that he had to declare interests in the coal industry because he declared his directorship in the company. What he did not do was declare his shareholding in the company. When he became a minister, he had to give up the directorship and chairmanship because it was on the public record. What he did not do was give up the shares, because he had never told anyone before. That is what we are on about here. We are on about the fact that Senator Parer has not disclosed what he is required in the parliament to disclose and what the Prime Minister's code of conduct requires him to disclose. There is no point in hiding behind that O'Keefe letter, which is what Senator Parer said he knew nothing about the other day. The fact of the matter is that the code of conduct for the Senate requires, in relation to the disclosure of shares, any shares that are held by a company that the minister and his family control-that is, IMPL. They control it. Nine out of nine shares are controlled by the minister and his wife-the family. Under the code of conduct in the Senate, Minister Parer, from day one, was required to declare that. I would urge the Prime Minister-I know he is not here; he does not like hearing this stuff-to go and do a bit of homework on this. There is no point trying to hide behind some device that says Senator Parer did not get a letter in 1997. He has been under obligation ever since he has been a senatorever since this code came in-to disclose it. What we have is a circumstance in which a minister has hidden his shareholding and it is a shareholding in an area of his portfolio responsibility. The fact that he has held it demonstrates that there can be not only the appearance of conflict of interest but also actual conflict of interest. This minister is guilty on both counts. He has failed to disclose. He has failed to dispose. The Prime Minister is required to ask for his resignation. If the Prime Minister's code of conduct means anything, he will enforce it. Minister Parer's resignation should be with us today. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The Australian public who are listening to this debate or who are in the gallery are going to ask themselves these questions this afternoon. Why is it that the Australian Labor Party is not interested in jobs for young Australians? Why is it that the Australian Labor Party has got nothing to say about interest rates? Why is it that the Australian Labor Party has got nothing to say about the state of the economy? Why is it that the Australian Labor Party, on the flimsiest of non-evidence whatsoever, can occupy the whole afternoon of this parliament in the pursuit of a non-issue? The answer is simply this: if you do not have a policy, if you do not have a record, if you do not have a position, if you do not have a direction and, what is more, if you do not have a leader, the thing you need more than anything else is distraction-distraction from those issues that the government is working on and distraction from those issues where your own incompetence is displayed. This censure is an absolute nonsense. Yesterday the chief muckraker for the Australian Labor Party-the man who stands at this dispatch box full of hate, venom and envy, the old President of the ACTU himself, the man who specialises in the parliamentary muckrake, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean)-came in here and held up a diagram which he alleged was a web of deceit, as I recall, until he was forced to withdraw it. He made out to this parliament that, in some form or fashion, Senator Parer had entered into some complicated arrangements to try to avoid disclosure requirements that were put in place as part of the code of conduct of this Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Of course, if you are a Prime Minister who has not got access to all of these diagrammatic matters, it takes some time to put it together. But, after the Prime Minister had put it together and spoken to his permanent head and investigated the file, not only did he find that all of these matters---every single one of these matters-had been fully disclosed but he found not that this arrangement, this trust, had been in existence as some device to avoid a ministerial conduct requirement which began to apply to Senator Parer from March 1996 but that this arrangement had been in place for 28 years. For 28 years Senator Parer had had this arrangement. It was no web of deceit to avoid anything. It was an arrangement that Senator Parer, whilst he was an execQtive in the coalrnining industry, had put in place to manage his family's finances. There was no web of deceit here, except from the dispatch box opposite-a web of deceit in an attempt to try to put together a diagram and to make allegations against Senator Parer which are wrong, false and unwarranted and which we reject in their entirety. This is an opposition which has engaged in a campaign of muckraking, and I want the Australian press to focus on this. Who was it that started the travel allowance fear and loathing campaign? It was Old Hotham, wasn't it? It was Old Hotham-the man who had been taking parliamentary visits to France to look at the change of government. He was the one who got up on the travel allowance matters, wasn'the? He was the one who went on national television, do you recall, and claimed that he had downloaded the DAS computer and was dealing in stolen property in relation to travel allowances? We all remember how his nice little number on travel allowances ended up in relation to the Australian Labor Party. Then last week we had this big campaign from the Australian Labor Party on the Natural Heritage Trust. Do you recall that campaign? This was the campaign that said that the Natural Heritage Trust had enriched Howard Lawrence Baillieu and Richard Percy Clive Baillieu as a result of allocations that had been made by this government after its election in March 1996. That allegation, which the Labor Party was able to run for a day, was disproved the next day when it was proved that, far from benefiting from the March 1996 Natural Heritage Trust, Howard Lawrence Baillieu had been dead for 37 years. That was the scandal-that from March 1996 we had been dishing out money to this dead man. Then we had,Richard Percy Clive Baillieu. He was another one of the beneficiaries out of the Natural Heritage Trust, according to the Australian Labor Party. He had been dead for 57 years. This really was a policy! Somehow we had managed to dish money out to dead men and they were getting a benefit---or so it was alleged by the Australian Labor Party. But we all know, as the member for Hotham knows more than anybody else, if you put the smear up, if you create enough smoke around, if you yell loudly enough, if you try to inject the politics of envy into it, you can fool the press gallery for a day or two, but the facts this case are not susceptible to any of the interpretations that he puts on them. The second thing that Old Hotham doesand he practised this in his ACTU days-is he tries to feed the politics of greed and You put the smoke up-it does not matter if you have a few dead men in there-and then you try to feed the politics of greed and envy. He said, 'There were these shares that were issued for $1 and then they became worth so much. They were issued in 1993 or 1995.' He said, 'Look at the poor people of Australia. They would want to know how to get into the act on this kind of thing.' How do the people of Australia get into the act on all of these sorts of share issues? I will tell you: join the Telstra float. The people of Australia who were given an opportunity by this government to join in on the part privatisation of Telstra ' got the opportunity to buy shares at $1.95 and they are now worth $3.60. What would Old Hotham say about that? 'Oh, outrageous! Every person who has Telstra shares should be sacked from their job!' That is probably the logic that he has got. Then he went on and he said-and listen to this; this is an absolute classic-'What is more, that company paid a fully franked dividend so that when it was paid to the shareholders it didn't get taxed again.' That is the whole object of franking. The Whole object of franking is to tax the dividend in the company so it is paid out to shareholders tax free. Is my memory serving me correct, or was it the Australian Labor Party that introduced full franking? I remember Mr Keating and Australian Labor Party members standing up and saying, 'We are going to introduce full franking so that dividends aren't taxed twice.' Then we have the economic genius from Hotham saying, 'They paid it out and it couldn't be taxed a second time.' These are the absolute intellectual depths to which these people will sink. Honestly, getting lectures from the member for Hotham on tax rorts! This was the old R&D syndicate man in the back of the Roller promising everybody R&D syndicates. This was the government that introduced infrastructure borrowings which made it optional to pay in tax if you were earning more than $500,000. Who closed that down? We did. Who closed down the R&D syndicates? We did. Who opposed us? The Australian Labor Party did. Who took measures in relation to superannuaenvy. tion? We did. Who opposed us? The Australian Labor Party did. This is the tactic which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition says includes walking along both sides of the street. That is what he calls it. Anyone who y..'ants a tax benefit walks on one side of the street, and when you want to run fear and envy politics you walk on the other side of the street. We do not walk on either side of the street-we walk right down the middle. That is our policy. We took decisions in relation to the R&D syndicates. We took on that particular rort and we closed it. We took a decision on infrastructure borrowing fair and square, and we closed it. When we were in opposition, the old member for Hotham, the old man who knew more about syndicates than anybody else, was not screaming at the dispatch box: he was on the other side of the street, or should I the back of the Roller on the other side of the street, in relation to those particular tax matters. Then the opposition said things like, 'Oh well, even if we cannot prove that there is anything wrong with the arrangements in relation to taxation because all they were doing was observing the law,' or even, 'We cannot prove that there was anything wrong in relation to the ownership of shares because they appreciated in accordance with the growth of the industry and the development of the mining industry.' We support the development of the coal mining industry . Would we be upset if the coal mining industry in Australia was actually developing wealth and creating jobs? We would not be upset by that. A lot of government policy is designed to do just that. Then the member for Hotham says, 'Oh well, there might have been the appearance of a conflict of interest.' What appearance of a conflict of interest was there in relation to this? Senator Parer had made a complete disclosure of that trust to the Corporate Trustee and to the Prime Minister, and the Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet had been fully notified of all of the events. They can point to no decision that Senator Parer took that was taken to advantage his private interests-not one. Yet the opposition now says that if there was no conflict of interest, there could have been an appearance of a conflict of interest because he had an interest as a minister in getting a profitable coal mining industry in Australia and he had been employed in the coal mining industry of Australia. Let me ask you this question: should a farmer who is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy who has an interest in getting a profitable agricultural sector in this country be disbarred from that particular office? Everyone engaged in economic portfolios has an interest in getting a profitable economy. Are we in a conflict of interest situation? Do people in this House who want more jobs for young people and who have children have a conflict of interest? Is it a conflict of interest to want to create jobs for young people when you have a young person say in in your family who is looking for a job? The upshot of the Labor Party positionand I cannot help but believe that it is deliberate-is that any person who has experience in any industry should be disqualified from making any decision in relation to that interest. The Labor Party maxim is: the more incompetent you are, the more qualified you are for office. On-can see why that suits their way of thinkirig. These are people who lecture about conflict of interest whilst they sit on the front bench of the opposition as members of trade unions. Members opposite keep up their trade union subscriptions and membership whilst still in the parliament. They vote on laws to give trade unions special privileges, special exemptions, special tax free status and special prerogatives under the law. That is not a conflict of interest, it is just doing your job as a good trade union member. There is an objective to try to put together rules which will uniquely disqualify qualified people from being engaged in any industry that they understand. It will lead to the qualification of only those who have a trade union background, because that is the way the Labor Party likes it. While watching the 7.30 Report on Tuesday 10 March I was amazed to see the Leader of the Opposition obviously being stung by his own record which is coming back to haunt him. He made the claim-and it is one that he is going to hear a lot more about between now and the next election-that he was proud to have been a member of the Keating and Hawke governments. This is the man who talks to us about standards. The Keating government had a Prime Minister who owned a piggery while he was running banking and economic policy. The Leader of the Opposition used to stand up and defend him. I remember Mr Keating defending his ownership of the piggery and attacking the opposition-and this would sit really well with the member for Hotham's speech today-and Keating said to the coalition, which included Senator Parer: You are mostly scrubbers. Most of you have not got any ability zacks to your name. That was the Labor Party when they were in office attacking the coalition because we were not wealthy. That was the Keating government of which Mr Beazley was proud. That was the Keating government which defended Carmen Lawrence after a royal commission found that she had lied-an independent royal commission. Who was leading the defence then? None other than the Leader of the Opposition. He was the man who defended Brian Burke. He used to come to this dispatch box and talk about his mate Brian Burke, and now that he is in office-this man who is proud of the Keating government and its standards-the Leader of the Opposition has suddenly seen a Damascan light. He now believes that standards should be higher than anything he could possibly have adhered to or supported while he was in government. He is nothing but a fraud. If he really believed in ministerial standards he would have a vacancy in his shadow ministry today. Have a look at old Senator Bolkus. There is no lack of evidence on him. Senator Bolkus is on film handing out particular documents. When he was caught on film, he tried to cover it up. Senator Parer made a disclosure and told the Prime Minister; Senator Bolkus covered it up and engaged in deceit. Semitor Bolkus gave out material which was banned from publicity by court order. What is more, Senator Bolkus threatened the rights of third parties that had an interest in the return of Christopher Skase to this country. There was a damage in that case: damage to the innocent small business creditors of Christopher Skase-the damaged third party. That is what makes it totally different. Senator Bolkus is a would be first law officer ofÂ· the Crown who was dealing in unauthorised material-caught on video trying to cover it up-and damaging third parties. That is the kind of person who ought to be sacked. This is a totally nonsensical censure motion designed to cover up the Bolkus affair, designed to cover up a lack of policy and to advance the muckraking of the member for Hotham. We reject the Beazley censure or two and we censure Senator Bolkus instead. I move: That the question be now put. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, in your capacity as having responsibility for the Joint House Department, I wonder whether you might look into the appointment of the managers position of the parliamentary recreation centre. I understand that Alison Porritt, who has occupied that position as manager for four years, and who has been an employee for eight years, has been overlooked for subsequent appointment to that position. Most members and senators who regularly attend that facility believe that Alison Porritt is an excellent officer of the department. I wonder whether you might investigate whether or not there is the opportunity, perhaps, Ms Porritt to be reconsidered for that position. others.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I will treat the question as a question on notice, and I will respond to you next week. Sound Recording

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, my question arises from today's question time when I noticed with some concern that, after you had ruled a particular member out of order and asked her to resume her seat, she continued to speak very loudly and at great length. My concern, Mr Speaker, is that the microphone remained on. It seems to me that it would be wise-and I wonder if you could arrange for it to be done-to arrange to have the microNOES phone turned off when you ask a member to take their seat.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I thank the honourable minister for her question. In fact, that step has already been taken. Speaker: Election

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, my question is PAIRS addressed to you. I draw your attention to an article at page 21 of this week's Bulletin written by David Robb.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Andrew!

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Andrew Robb; I am sorry. They are obviously reliable sources. The assertion is made in that article that an arrangement has been made that, if you are to retain the speakership should the government Centre be returned after the next election, that will require the National Party to give up one of its ministries. Can you confirm to the House whether such an undertaking was given by you to the Prime Minister?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I am interested to note the confidence the honourable member for Hotham has in .the return of the government. Those events to take place after the election will be for the government that is elected, and there are obviously no commitments-nor have there been-on any position, including the leadership or any other position with any party, as they are all a matter of election. As to any position that I might have, I can assure you that there are no undertakings other than for those that have been disclosed by myself and Quality of Debate  the lead-up, and on your election to the position of Speaker-for which I sincerely congratulate you-you made remarks which expressed the view that you would like to see an improved quality of debate in this chamber. Has your attention been drawn to the frequency with which honourable members read speeches? Will you consider the issue with a view to encouraging more extemporaneous contributions during debate?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I would be delighted if that were possible. I think we all recognise that, for right or wrong reasons, more and more members are reading speeches. I think it is a pity but, sadly, a standing order that was in place many years ago which required that far more speeches be made without referring to written material has now been deleted. Any change to the standing orders regarding the reading of speeches may well be best referred to the Standing Committee on Procedure, and I will direct your question to the committee. Speaker: Election

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr SPeaker, my question to you relates to an article by Alan Ramsay which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald last weekend in which the assertion was made that the Prime Minister offered you the speakership two weeks after the Constitutional Convention. Mr Speaker, did the Prime Minister offer you the speakership at that time?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I responded to that question before; I said that there were discussions between the Prime Minister and me regarding the comparison between the standard of behaviour at the Constitutional Convention and the standard of behaviour in this place. I regret that it still remains the case that the standard of behaviour at the Constitutional Convention was of a far higher order. The Prime Minister invited me to assume this position when it became available after my predecessor, the honourable member for Casey, resigned his post. Quality of Debate

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, further to the matter raised by the member for Chifley-and I am speaking without notes-I would ask you, in your reference to the Standing Committee on Procedure, to examine the book recently published by Mr John Pasquarelli, The Pauline Hanson Story, which makes plain that for a long time every single word spoken in this place by the member for Oxley was written for her by a member of her staff, Mr Pasquarelli. I put it to you, for consideration by the committee, that, rightly or wrongly, the people of Oxley elected that person, Ms Hanson, to represent them and speak on their behalf in this place, not someone who is unelected. I think this is a very important document that needs to be drawn to the attention of the Standing Committee on Procedure further to the matters raised earlier. I ask you, as a former member of the New South Wales parliament, to examine their standing orders to make sure that members do make statements of their own accord in a representative and democratic fashion, instead of relying on the words of unelected people outside the parliament.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: With regard to the first question raised by the honourable member, no matter how wide the responsibilities of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I am afraid it lies well outside their compass. As to the second question, I will draw the attention of the Standing Committee on Procedure to the standing orders of each other parliament in Australia, including that of the parliament of New South Wales. Question Time Mr ROSS .CAMERON- Mr Speaker, while the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Hotham are renowned-and the grandmaster champion is the member for Holt-for making tortuous introductory statements, in light of the question put by the member for Chifley, and noting that the member for Perth asked two questions today which I think a reading of the Hansard will show contained no fewer than 15 questions in the two visits he made to the dispatch box, I ask you: what will your attitude be towards multiple questions and tortuous introductory statements?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION
text: We had to stop this debate just before question time, and I had only one or two minutes to try to sum up the debate. I will resume by saying that I thank the colleagues from Â·both sides who spoke on this matter. There was a range of contributions, some particularly good and some vested with emotion, as you would 1998 expect and as we see sometimes when we have discussions about child care. Fundamentally, the proposals that we are dealing with in the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 relate to some changes to make child-care assistance easier for families. Our researcp conducted last year showed that the arrangements envisaged under the Child Care Payments Act would be difficult to families and services during 1998, and the changes that we have made try to address those problems. That has been met with acclaim from across the child-care sector. I am grateful for that. I particularly notice the press release from Mr Kemp from Australian child care centres, who was indicating that they were very pleased with what had been done by the government in responding to their concerns. There are other groups: the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations, the Care Bear Child Care Centre in Mornington, the Uniting Church Children's Services Forum in New South Wales, and the National Family Day Care Council in New South Wales as well and many others. All indicated that they appreciated the changes that had been made. The changes that are made have been made to the primary act-the child care bill of last year, which the Labor Party supported. Fundamentally, it addresses the needs of establishing a sustainable planning process for child care in this country. The arrangements also put in place some other additional matters which we probably should not discuss at length today, but there is a continuation and a commitment to the arrangements with regard to immunisation. Age appropriate immunisation proceedings will become a requirement for payment of both child-care assistance and child-care rebate. The link between that immunisation and child-care payments will involve some changes which are picked up in this amendment bill. All of us in this place understand the importance of furthering the need for immunisation of our young people in this country, and this is a very positive way of dealing with it. There is the issue of the 20-hour limit for non-work related child care. There is a limitation there, and that continues on in this amendment bill. I know there were some concerns about this issue, and I have indicated to the industry I certainly will listen to the views that they put to me on that particular matter. This amendment bill covers only long day care centres and the corresponding changes for other services, including outside school hours care services, will be implemented administratively. I might make some other comments about some of the remarks, and I am going to curtail my remarks because there is not much time today. There is a second reading amendment which was moved by the Labor Party, which I understand they want to divide on. Obviously I can say on behalf of the government that we reject the amendment. It is possessed of politics and .does not further the debate about enhancing quality or dealing with the administrative arrangements for the changes in child care, which will start on 27 April. I might just make the point with regard to outside school hours care, because that has been the focus of some of the comment from colleagues today. It should be understood that there are about 2,000 .out of school hours care services in this country. About 70,000 families have been using those services but, after 27 April, some 51,000 families will have access to child-care assistance for the first time. I think that is a fact that is escaping the attention of many people. There will be changes in administrative arrangements. The arrangements will be done primarily by the service provider, but they are provided with an amount of some $20 million to make the administrative load that much easier. They are funds that they have asked for. I have said that I will keep that under review, and I am in continual discussion with them. Out of school hours care is a very important service. It is an addition to the choice that is available to families as they pursue their work and study options to have that broader range of choice: family day care, community care, private care and outside school hours careall very important. We want to ensure that that choice, is there, and it is a meaningful choice. We also want to ensure thatÂ· the assistance that we are providing to child care in this country reaches the parents. This is what has been done. The changes in outside school hours care follow a two-year study as to how best we might advantage families that are using these services. This was a study commenced by the Labor Party, as I pointed out in question time during the week, and they would have reached the same conclusion that we did: that this was socially and equitably the far better way for us to proceed to provide this assistance. I think that needs to be taken into account as well. The administrative burden that the outside school hours care providers will be feeling will be ameliorated by the extensive support that they will receive from these additional funds and the training and support from the department officers right around the country. I hope that they will make the commitment to ensure that, when we come to the change point on 27 April, we will be able to have a smooth change. We have established 1800 numbers for access by parents. I think that, when they make inquiries about their entitlements of child-care assistance and child-care rebates and about the locations of relevant services, they will find that the system is working particularly well. We have high call numbers now. I feel confident that, on testing the systems, parents will find that the child-care system we are putting in place will be more than adequate for their needs and the aspirations that they would have for their children. Finally, I indicate that the level of support for child care in this country is very extensive. We will spend in the vicinity of $5 bHlion over the next four years. There will be 83,000 new places, additional places, over the next four years. Nearly 600,000 children will be involved in some form of formal child care. We have had an 18 per cent increase over the last two years in outlays in child care, yet we find in this amendment a reference to forward estimates that were preexisting. The Labor Party cannot have it both ways. They commit themselves to the need for planning, which was the feature of the primary bill and which the Labor Party in the Senate supported, but at the same time as a consequence of putting in a planning regime that limits a sustained growth in child-care centres, which is supported by the child-care industry, there obviously will be those savings to the broad range of taxpayers. I think that needs to be seen for what it is. I understand politics, and this is a political issue. We have seen circulars sent around the country by the LHMU, the union that covers some of the child-care workers. Really this is just another distortion, a scare campaign, that we have seen in other areas. I think it is regrettable. I do not think it is necessary to scare the parents of this country in the way that it has been done. The Jacts should be known. The service providers know the facts and they also believe that, following 27 April-and this bill gives effect to that change-the administrative arrangements will be that much easier for the child-care providers and for parents, and we can proceed with delivering better quality child care to this country. WithÂ· those few remarks, I again thank all colleagues for their contribution to an interestingÂ· debate and indicate that the government opposes the second reading amendment.
