Speaker: Ms ELLIS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am extremely disappointed to see how the Minister for the Status of Women (Mrs Moylan) is tackling her portfolio. I imagine she was disappointed at her demotion in the ministry. After all, she had done what was asked of her. She was the minister responsible for cutting $800 million from child care. She was the minister responsible for cutting $500 million from aged care. For a government NA driven by the dollar bottom line this should have been an applauded outcome. At least we thought that with her appointment as Minister for the Status of Women some consideration would finally be given by this government to the concerns of Australian women and that she might even realise what her actions in child care and aged care have meant to Australian women given that appointment. What do we see? Since parliament has resumed this year this minister has taken at least two questions I can recall from her own side seeking advice on the government's initiatives that have assisted Australian women. All she has done in answering those questions is attack the Labor Party and refer to some preselection process over which the minister has somehow taken offence. I take this opportunity to inform the minister, if she is so offended by what we happen to be doing in our preselection process, about six safe PAIRS seats. The new candidates are: Lalor, Julia Gillard; Gellibrand, Nicola Roxon; Shortland, Jill Hall; Charlton, Kelly Hoare; Fowler, Julia Irwin; and Sydney, Tanya Plebicek. A lot has happened since this government took office which has affected Australian women. There is much this minister should be concerned about and of far more importance than the personal offence she seems to have taken to the ALP preselection process. Since the Howard government came to power in 1996, Australian women have found it harder to find jobs, harder to get wage increases, harder to pay for child care, harder to pay for health care, harder to pay for their children's education and harder to pay for aged care. It is Australian women who have paid the ultimate price for the Howard government's deep cut to health, education and community services. The message from the Howard government to Australian women is clear. When it comes to balancing work and family responsibilities you are on your own. In the work area, over 300,000 women are currently unemployed and 86,000 of these have been unemployed for over one year. Less than 30,000 new jobs have been created for women since the government came to power. I asked a question in the House yesterday about the 50,000 married women who will be denied free access to employment services because of this government. In the pay packet the gap between what men and women earn is widening. Child-care costs have risen as much as $20 a week in some centres to make up for the $820 million this government has ripped out of that system. The Prime Minister has increased the maximum cost of a prescription for families from $17.40 to $20. For a pensioner that price has gone from $2.70 to $3.20. Fees for university have more than doubled under this government. University places have been cut by 21,000. Now that young people, those who can afford it, can buy their way into university the principle of merit thrown out the window and women attempting to get benefit from education expansion in the 1980s are now denied it. In nursing homes, women live longer than men and are more likely to need that sort of care. Under the Howard government, all nursing home patients with assets of over $22,500, including the family home, will have to pay an annual fee of up to $4,380 a year for five years. Should families decide that they cannot afford this nursing home fiasco, it is usually the woman in the family who takes on that caring role. Women are really doing it tough under Howard. Most Australian families rely on two incomes to make ends meet. When jobs cannot be found or childcare costs are simply too high, it is the family income that suffers and the women have to find a way to heal that. These issues urgently need the attention of the Minister for the Status of Women. I suggest very strongly that she tum her attention to them accordingly. Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: NOES
text: I  does not object: I actually gave a bit of thought to this adjournment speech and wrote a few notes. Now that the emotion is starting to settle down in relation to the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras that is held in Sydney, I would like to make a few comments about it. I confess to not pulling on my orange lycra shorts to go to the mardi gras. I would like to preface what I have to say, though, by making a couple of serious remarks. My mother lost one of her two sons to AIDS. She did so having done everything she could to instil in both her sons a deeply imbued sense of what was right and wrong. Such is the nature of society that my brother lived with this virus for six years until, in 1990, he summoned the courage to first let me know of his problem and then his parents. It was in that context that a couple of months ago, like most members of the New South Wales community, I became aware of the fact that the police, at that stage at least, had been advised that they would be able to march in the mardi gras and to do so in uniform, and that they would be paid. Subsequently, of has been course, that decision was changed. There are a couple of points that need to be made. I think that society, in an environment where we are not leading up to the mardi gras, needs to have some serious and perhaps sober discussion about what this event is really all about. I find it a near impossible task to teach my own children what the difference is between what is right and what is wrong. I question whether it is made any easier by having gay and lesbian men and women making quite hurtful parodies of some of the most caring groups in the communitythe Sisters of Charity for one-and the state appearing to endorse this kind of behaviour, which under most circumstances we would not accept, whatever the sexuality of the participants. We see politicians from all political parties falling over one another to endorse the mardi gras, to embrac- and encourage the gay vote or the gay lobby, and this is seen to be an end which justifies the means. I question whether that is the right thing for us to be doing. As parents-and I am one of them-struggle to explain the difference between what is right and wrong to children in their early teens, I ask: how is this near impossible task assisted in any way by the state appearing to condone a form of behaviour that most of us find difficult to understand, let alone tolerate? At issue, to me at least, is not the sexuality of the participants-it has nothing to do with that-but the hurtful parodies of some of the most caring and sincere groups in the community, public nakedness that borders on indecency, and th- performance of acts that few adults could explain to the inquiring minds of children. Were this a dignified parade tb protest the cruel injustices and prejudice faced in day to day life by homosexual people, I would be prepared to not only join it but to lead it. In that regard, I must say that I have considerable sympathy for what I understand will be a private member's motion to be brought on by the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) in relation to superannuation entitlements for same sex couples. Instead-to me at least-the gay mardi gras stands alongside gambling, drug use, escalating suicide rates, and debates about euthanasia and race, as further evidence of a society that is seriously failing. There is in the end a difference between right and wrong. Homosexual people are our brothers and sisters, our aunts and uncles, our sons and daughters, and some are even parents, and they should be able to live in a society that is free of intolerattend ance, persecution and hatred. Yet they should also understand and respect a societal view that any moral and economic priority should dictate that police and-dare I say-politicians and others who profess to lead should be anywhere other than at a parade such as the mardi gras. I realise that I am probably alienating some of my constituents and many others who will now make me a parody and a subject of abuse. But I believe in what I have said and I think that there is a time that many of us who profess to lead stood up and said, 'Hang on, why don't you hose yourselves down a bit and behave in a different way?' Convention on the Civil Aspects of Internationfll Child Abduction

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: NOES
text: I rise this evening to present this extremely disturbing issue surrounding the Hague Convention on the Ci vii Aspects of International Child Abduction, which dates back to 1980. One of my constituents, Maria Acanfora, migrated to Australia from Italy in 1974 as a lO-year-old girl. She is being harassed and pursued by hyr Italian husband via the state central authority nominated under the terms of the convention-in this case the Victorian Department of Human Services. Maria, an Australian citizen, resident in Australia for more than 20 years, left Australia for a holiday to Italy in 1994 where she met an Italian man whom she decided to marry. They were married in Italy on 5 May 1994. They lived in Bologna in Italy until July 1995 when they moved to the Honduras. Their son, Francesco, was born there on 12 October 1995. They both returned to Australia in December 1995, then went back to Bologna in February 1996. Unable to find work in Italy, the couple returned to Australia in November 1996 to start up business and to settle in Australia permanently. The marriage broke down. In order to stop her husband carrying out his threat of taking their very young son back to Italy, Ms Acanfora took out a court order on 17 March, which was served on the husband on 18 March 1997. Her husband did not the hearing, scheduled for 19 March; instead, he packed his bags and went back to Italy. Between 19 March 1997 and 2 December, the only contact attempted with the child by the father was three faxes-which was pretty hopeful given that the child was between 17 months old and two years old during this tirne and therefore not able to read. On 1 December last year, an ex parte writ under the Family Law (Child Abduction Conventions) Regulations applying to have the child returned to Italy was issued in the Family Court of Australia for hearing. Why it was served and considered ex parte is a mystery to me, as the respondent,' Ms Acanfora, was quite readily contactable. She was in fact living in the home that she had always lived in and, indeed, the home that she had lived in with her husband during their time together in Australia. She was so easily contactable that the next day, 2 December, she was visited at her place of residence by three Federal Police officers and two social workers, and both the mother and child were taken to court. Her passports were retained until the outcome of the hearing, and the is still residing with her in the family home. My concern about this issue is that, apparently, according to the convention, the taxpaywould er is to pay the legal expenses for the father, who is living in Italy, yet the expenses of Ms Acanfora, who is my constituent and an Australian citizen, will not be picked up by anybody. She has applied for and has been denied legal aid. I am also most concerned that the initial hearing, was heard and held ex parte for no legitimate reason as the mother was directly contactable. I do not believe this is an approI priate way for Australian citizens to have access to the law and for their rights to be heard. I believe that ex parte hearings should be only in extreme circumstances, where someone flees the country to avoid justice and so on. They should not be for a case like this where she was quite easy to find. This is a misuse of a convention that was designed honourably and with good intent to protect the lives of abducted children across international boundaries. It would appear in this case, however, to be the means by which an Australian citizen of long standing is not being given fair treatment. You have to question the sense of a convention that provides the international challenger with the might of free legal representation while an Australian citizen gets none. There seems to me to be something quite wrong about this. I will just refer to the latest letter that she has received from Victoria Legal Aid. It states: Your matter does not come under the Family Law Act, the Child Support (Assessment) Act or the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act. Therefore, she cannot receive legal aid. What we appear to have is a situation where foreign nationals can pursue family law matters with the assistance of legal aid but we do not have legal aid for Australian citizens. I also add that it is highly doubtful that the son should be regarded as an Italian citizen, given that he was born in the Honduras and his next place of residence for a considerable time was Australia. There seems to me to be some very unsatisfactory features about this child case which warrant further consideration. Kernot, Ms Cheryl

Title: NOES
text: Yes. She is a dishonest person. I must move on because I have a fair bit to say about this duplicitous, disingenuous person called Cheryl Kernot. She went to rent a house and a truck went through it, so then she said she was off to rent somewhere else. My information is that she may have rented a place there, but she does not live there. I reliably informed that she lives in an inner city penthouse in Brisbane called Admiralty Towers. This is a great commitment to the people of Dickson, isn't it? She will go and be their member, but she will not live in their electorate. She is not going to live in a nice little house in the electorate; she is going to live in a penthouse. She is a member of the Labor Party, but she is certainly not a member of parliament and, in my opinion, she will not get that four per cent-she's got Buckley'S. But her own staff found out via the media. That was the way she found out. I also happen to know that some of these people have mortgages to pay-but there was no job the next day. They have mortgages to pay. They have feelings. Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: NOES
text: Grayndler) (5.45 p.m.)I rise to put on record my disappointment and anger on behalf of my constituents in Sydenham in Sydney. When Mark Vaile became the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, to his credit, he visited my electorate on 31 October 1997-something that his predecessor, John Sharp, had failed to do, despite a number of promises-to look first hand at the impact the airport noise issue was having in the area closest to Sydney airport. During that visit, we walked around with Joe Hockey, the chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum; Barry Cotter, the Mayor of Marrickville; and other community representatives. We wanted to show the minister first-hand what the issues were and how they needed to be resolved. Unfortunately, just before parliament came back, we received replies from the minister which were all in the negative. On the issue of small businesses in Sydenham, as the House would be aware, as a result of the decision to build the third runway a whole section of Sydenham was deemed to be unliveable in-that is, above 40 ANEF. Some 151 houses were bought and demolished in that area. This had an effect on the local shopping centre, not surprisingly. Of the 17 businesses there, a majority have closed. It is not surprising that when you take away the houses from a community the local paper shop, milk bar, takeaway, florist, and hardware store are forced to close. That was a direct result of a decision of government. While other people closest to the airport were eligible for insulation, these small business owners got exactly zero. The shops were not insulated, yet many of the shopkeepers live above their shops. These are working people, mainly of migrant backgrounds, who settled in Australia and have worked hard to build up their businesses and support their families. Those businesses are today not worth a red cent. I believe that they have a legitimate claim for compensation, especially from a government that says that it cares about small business. These people got nothing from the minister. He did not even bother to write back to them. Instead, they got a letter through the Chair the Sydney Airport Community Forum which said that, while the minister had some sympathy for' them, he was not able to support their claim for compensation. Sympathy will not feed the children of those hard working families. The Sydney Airport Community Forum is a government appointed body which, in spite of being stacked with representatives from the North Shore of Sydney, has carried resolutions unanimously supporting the demands of these people. People like Joe Hockey, the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), state Liberal members and Liberal mayors, people like Kerry Chikarovski and others have all supported these claims, yet the government says that it is not going to deliver on it. That is a disgrace. We also visited weatherboard houses which had been insulated. That insulation had had a minimal impact on noise reduction. Spending $47,000 insulating the walls of weatherboard houses is a complete waste of money. The government should have just handed over a cheque. We had a plan for the voluntary acquisition of those homes-a plan which was once again unanimously supported by the Sydney Airport Community Forum. Once again, that unanimous support meant nothing when it came to the minister's decision. It is a very poor performance indeed from the minister when government members are saying, 'You've got a case. We agree with you unanimously. We think this is an issue of justice,' but the government will not pay a minimal amount of money, an amount which would not have come out of taxation revenue but from the airport tax on each ticket. These people deserve better. (Time expired) Superannuation

Speaker: Mr TONY SMITH
Title: NOES
text: It is a mark of a mature politician that he has the sensitivity and wisdom to admit an error of judgment, a lack of understanding and a failure to properly read a situation. Many great politicians have demonstrated these qualities. They have recognised mistakes. They have said sorry. They have responded. Political life is a difficult and complex one. Some would say that modem of political life is almost unbearable, with its - onstant pressures from either side ofÂ· an lssue. However, it is important to remember that the people of Australia, the ordinary people, are our ultimate masters-not political parties, not unelected officials, not pollsters, not the politically correct elite and not the juste milieu who seem to dictate what we are supposed to say, do and act upon. That is why we must be strong in this game-strong enough to stand up to those who purport to tell us what to do, especially some of the revolting media outlets which want to run the country from an office in New York or some other remote locality. I could not help but be moved by a letter to the Sydney Daily Telegraph which was published on 10 March 1998. It is critical of the government, but I believe that we should all listen to it, no matter what side of politics we are on. It says: Mr Howard's political agenda is further evidence of how out of touch he is with those who go through the pain of divorce and settlement. I started my superannuation fund before I was married. During my divorce settlement I was placed in the position of closing down a business or handing the business over in exchange for keeping my superannuation. Selling the business as part of my divorce settlement would have benefited me little. Handing this over to my ex-wife saved my superannuation, it kept her self-employed and while it operates, it provides a great livelihood. My superannuation left something for me to pass on for our son. John Howard may know the price of milk but does he know the anguish that a father also goes through when a marriage ends? It is not only the woman who has to endure this trauma. Is he aware that male rights for joint custody is still a major battle for some? Is he aware of how difficult it is to re-establish one's life when 18 per cent of your gross incomefor one childgoes towards maintenance? My divorce settlement left me the equivalent of what I started with before my 10 years of marriage. If we have to give up our superannuation will this enable males the same rights in divorce hearings? Will males be entitled to an ex-wife's superannuation? Let's change the Family Law court system, before we create more turmoil in divorce settlements. I have watched our son grow, but I have had limited opportunities at tucking him into bed every night and picking him up and taking him to school or holding him in my arms when he is sick. I would give up my superannuation tomorrow for the chance to be with my son. Name and address supplied but withheld for legal reasons Those words moved me. Not only do they echo the pain of my constituents but also they stir inner personal experience. Last Sunday I saw my nine-year-old son walking down the street. I had not seen him for a year-a separation not caused by a deliberate choice of mine. As I spoke to him and adjusted my eyes to the fact of the changes and his growth, the pain of loss was indescribable. I feel for the writer who understandably withheld his name for legal reasons. I have seen the shocking excesses of the Child Support Agency that leaves people broken, penniless and suicidal, and the failure of the Family Law Act to address marital breakdown. I listen daily to my constituents and to many others from all over Australia who have been blighted by the iniquitous system. Despite the heading in the Sydney Morning Herald after the government's announcement, women will not win. Dividing people means no winners but bitter losers. Neither money nor slogans can ameliorate the heartache and pain of separation and alienation from your kids and the loneliness. My electorate is demanding fairness in the family law system and major changes to the Child Support Agency and I am listening to it. Nothing will deter me from doing my duty and representing my constituents. Employment

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: NOES
text: I rise to speak about the Howard government's lack of performance on the second anniversary of its election with respect to jobs. In doing so, I also refer in passing to a media release by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs today which states: The Government's policies have laid the foundation for continued jobs growth this year. ' It then refers in passing to the participation rate: The participation rate was steady at 63.2%. It is appropriate that we place the real facts on record this evening, and what a terrible record this government' s p-rformance is on the jobs front. In doing so, I refer to the Prime Minister's statement exactly two years ago. This is what he had to say on the eve of the last federal election at the National Press Club: I will be a very disappointed man if I have not made very serious inroads into the level of yout4 unemployment in this country because I would like to see our performance in that area as being the mark of what we' have been able to do as a government. Two years on, 1 would have thought that there is something to talk about this afternoon. Where are we two years on? It is interesting to note, ,on the second anniversary of the election of the Howard government, on the second anniversary of what I suppose was a core promise-I doubt it is a core promise any more-youth unemployment remains static at 26.4 per cent. I suppose he will be revising a few other promises as we move towards the next election: the concepts of core and non-core according to performance and non-performance. Let us deal with the comparison of the first two years of this government on the jobs front with the last two years of Labor in government, the most readily available comparison as to performance. Let us deal firstly with the issue of total jobs growth. There are a range of indicators that we can consider this afternoon. Concerning total jobs growth, John Howard, the Prime Minister of Australia, in his first 24 months of government has achieved 193,100 jobs. In their last 24 months, the Labor Party achieved 521,100 jobs. I now go to the issue of full-time jobs growth. John Howard in his first 24 months as Prime Minister: 75,700-a staggering performance. The Labor Party in its last 24 months: 322,700. I would hate to think what he was achieving if the jobs growth was not on target at this point in time. Part-time jobs growth: 117,400-a real achievement for John Howard. Labor's part-time jobs growth in the last 24 months: 198,400. Then we go to the staggering reduction in unemployment that has been achieved in John Howard's first two years of government: 0.3 per cent. Youth unemployment is stuck at a national level, the overall level of unemployment is down 0.3 per cent. What did Labor achieve in our last 24 months? Not a bad result: a reduction of two per cent. Now we go to the participation rate. In many ways the participation rate is, in people's minds, a statement of their view or their sense of confidence in their capacity to get a job based on the performance of the economy and the performance of the government. It is interesting to note that people have actually given up hope of finding a job. The participation rate has dropped in the two years from 63.8 percent to 63.2 per cent. I suppose he has achieved something. He has driven men and women out of the work force and placed barriers especially in the face of women who want to make a contribution to the development of Australia and, in so doing, try to secure and create better opportunities for their families in the future. I belif<ve that the Prime Minister is trying to hide these stark figures of his fudge on the employrnent front. He is trying to point the finger at the underprivileged in the Australian community and he stands condemned this afternoon for his failure. Worse still, the changes in the delivery of employment services is an absolute disgrace. To deny married women whose husbands are working, to deny the spouses of defence personnel an opportunity to get a job, to deny young people who are not on benefits but seeking to pursue training, be it in TAFE or universities, the opportunity to use the old CES to get a joba leg up the ladder-is an absolute disgrace. This government is not committed to jobs and job security. Its first two years of a lack of performance show that. On all the indicators-full-time jobs growth, part-time jobs growth-the question of what you do with respect to the participation rate and youth employment are an absolute failure and disgrace. (Time Main Committee adjourned at 12.59 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Agreement (Question No. 2414) Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 23 October 1997: Will the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Agreement allow a New Zealand commercial pilot's licence and instructor's rating to be used Australia; if so, when will the Agreement be operational. NA Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Under the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Arrangement (TTMRA), a person who is registered to practise an occupation in New Zealand is entitled to practise an equivalent occupation in Australia. The TTMRA will therefore allow for a New Zealand commercial pilot's licence and instructor's rating to be used in Australia on the basis of equivalence. The proposed Arrangement requires individuals possessing such licences, and wishing to utilise them in the other country, to in register with the aviation authority of the country concerned. It is anticipated that the Arrangement will become effective from 1 May 1998.
